div.p:
As the different courses of
lectures delivered at Charing Cross Hospital are soon
to terminate for the season, and no clinical
lectures being given there during the summer
months, it was thought desirable that I should
have an opportunity of witnessing the practice &
attending the clinical lectures of some other
hospital -

St Bartholomew's being the most
eligible for that purpose, both on account
of its situation and other lectures in addition
to the clinical, such as Midwifery & the diseases
of women and children, Medical physics, Botany &c.
Dr J.B. Bennet, through whose influence, admission
to the hospital at Charing Cross was gratuitously
afforded, endeavoured to procure the same
at Bartholomew's but the authorities there
having taken his request into consideration
resolved that missionary students should not
now as formerly be admitted gratis, but that
admission to at least one department of the hospital
should be purchased & if so then all the other
advantages of the hospital are to the thrown open
to them -

Hoping, that my requesting for the fee for
the medical practice, which is the lowest on
the list, will not be considered an unnecessaryunnecessary
demand on the funds of the society.

P.S. the advantages cannot be transferred
nor can we pay the fee for a shorter period
than 9 months.
